item.title: Community Structures
item.description: Using the Louvain clustering algorithm, we optimize for modularity score and get a partitioning with a modularity of around 0.35. Giving us an approximately 36% and 75% percent increase compared to party-chamber and party-party partioning respectively, indicating that there indeed is a third dimension to the way the congressial communities organize themselves, beyond party and party-chamber. In the matrix below, we have compared how the members of the different parties have spread themselves out across the Louvain-based partitionings.

item.title: Data description
item.description: To perform this analysis we need to collect tweets from member of the United States Congress. An ideal way to do this, would be to call the twitter api and request tweets in a specific time period with hastags or accounts names that mathces with member of the congress. However, this approach is not feasible after Twitter has changed their policy when Mr. Musk accouired the company. Therefore, we have used the public available dataset of US Congress tweets hosted on github and part of the open source project Congressional Tweet Automator.

item.title: Network Structure
item.description: We want to start by investigating the network structure. Specifically, we want to investigate the mixing patterns based on parties. As a starting point, we compute the fraction of out edges that connects to users with the same party affiliation.
